metadata.title: Seed-mediated superior organometal halide films by GeO2 nano-particles for high performance perovskite solar cells

sections.text:
Seed-mediated superior organometal halide films by GeO2 nano-particles for high performance perovskite solar cells
Yan-Hui Lou, Meng Li, and Zhao-Kui Wang,
Citation: Appl. Phys. Lett. 108, 053301 (2016); doi: 10.1063/1.4941416 View online: http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4941416 View Table of Contents: http://aip.scitation.org/toc/apl/108/5 Published by the American Institute of Physics
Seed-mediated superior organometal halide films by GeO2 nano-particles for high performance perovskite solar cells
Yan-Hui Lou,1 Meng Li,2 and Zhao-Kui Wang2,a) 1College of Physics, Optoelectronics and Energy, Soochow University, Suzhou, Jiangsu 215123, China 2Institute of Functional Nano and Soft Materials (FUNSOM), Soochow University, Suzhou, Jiangsu 215123, China
(Received 9 November 2015; accepted 25 January 2016; published online 3 February 2016)
The authors developed a seed-mediated method by GeO2 nano-particles (NPs) for growing crystal perovskite films. Poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythiophene):poly(4-styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS)-GeO2 composite films can act as an efficient underlayer for the growth of crystal perovskite films. GeO2 NPs are regarded as the growing sites of crystal nucleus of the perovskites. Superior quality of per-
ovskite films are achieved by tuning the size of the GeO2 NPs, which results in a power conversion efficiency as high as 16.77%. The seed-mediated growing route on perovskite crystallization also
gives a hint to seek other nano-particle materials for fabricating highly efficient and stable
perovskite solar cells in the future. VC 2016 AIP Publishing LLC. [http://dx.doi.org/10.1063/1.4941416]
With efforts, the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of
organometal halide perovskite solar cells (PSCs) has increased dramatically, with a certified 20.1%.1 Recently,
planar structure PSCs have drawn much attention because it
can facilitate a simple fabrication for low-temperature and solution-processing devices.2–5 With controllable interface
and crystal growth engineering, PSCs based on planar struc-
ture have demonstrated comparable efficiency with the meso-porous ones.6–10 In typical planar structure PSCs, per-
ovskite absorber layer is sandwiched between the hole- and
electron-selective contact layers, which play important role
in manipulating the carriers along the whole pathway from
the active layer to electrodes. For electron interfacial materi-
als, LiF, bathocuproine (BCP), fullerene (C60), and solution-
processed polyelectrolyte or amino functionalized polymer have been utilized in PSCs.4,11–15 However, limited hole
interfacial materials, generally, poly(3,4-ethylene dioxythio-
phene):poly(4-styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS) and 2,2,7, 7-tetrakis(N,N0di-p-methoxyphenylamine)-9,9-spirobiuorene (spiro-OMeTAD), are reported in inverted PSCs.7,16–18 What is more, there are large issues of hygroscopic nature19
of the aqueous PEDOT:PSS dispersions and the high price
of spiro-OMeTAD, which would restrict the device reliabil-
ity and increase the device cost, respectively.
Recently, solution-processed transition metal oxides
(TMOs) materials have been used in organic solar cells as
the anode interfacial layer because of their comparable effi-
ciency and improved device performance compared with PEDOT:PSS-based cells.20–23 However, few studies were
reported on these solution-processed TMO interfacial layer
based perovskite solar cells. Recently, nickel oxide (NiOx) p-type interface layer has been utilized in perovskite solar
cells. For example, Xu et al. reported NiOx based PSCs with a PCE of 14.9%.24 You et al. obtained high-performance PSCs with a PCE of 16.1% and largely improved cell stabil-
ity by using NiOx and other metal oxide as the interfacial
materials.25 As a matter of fact, the growth of the perovskite
crystal films, including the final film uniformity, crystal qual-
ity in terms of grain size, and crystal orientation, strongly depends on the underlayer conditions.26–29 Great efforts of
the contact matching between the underlayer and the perov-
skite active layer, including the surface, interface, and
the energy levels, are necessary when these solution-
processed TMO materials are used in perovskite solar cells.
Particularly, critical growth of the crystal perovskite films
restricts the application of many common TMO underlayer
materials. Actually, crystal growth of the perovskite films is
a complicated process. The crystalline kinetics of the perov-
skite films is associated with the precursor composition,
solvent choice, annealing temperature, and so on. Many methods, i.e., solution-based hot-casting technique,30 layer-
by-layer fabrication process based on air exposure followed by thermal annealing,31 solvent-induced fast crystallization,32 and water additive induced crystallization,10 have
been reported to improve the crystalline quality of the perov-
skite films. These reported means are mostly based on the
control of the perovskite active layer itself. To further
improve the device performance and decrease the fabrication
cost, other simple and practical techniques in controlling the
growth of crystalline perovskite films are necessary to be
developed.
GeO2 has certain solubility in water. 7,33 It provides a simple route for GeO2 to deposit a thin film via solution processing. Unfortunately, direct trial of GeO2 as a hole interfacial layer in perovskite solar cells similar as that in
organic solar cells cannot achieve satisfying device perform-
ance. Recently, we found that repetitive coating of GeO2 films onto ITO can act as a good underlayer for perovskite
growth. With optimized treatment, uniform GeO2 film with good coverage can be deposited onto ITO substrates.
Accordingly, the resulting PSC device with GeO2-modified ITO anode shows a best PCE of 12.17%, which is compara-
ble with the PEDOT:PSS based devices (12.37%). More
importantly, GeO2-doped PEDOT:PSS demonstrates an a)E-mail: zkwang@suda.edu.cn
0003-6951/2016/108(5)/053301/5/$30.00 VC 2016 AIP Publishing LLC108, 053301-1
excellent platform for the perovskite growth. PEDOT:PSS in
the composite films served as a hole interfacial layer for the
perovskite solar cells. The aggregated GeO2 nano-particles (NPs) on the surface of the composite films can act as the
growing seed site of the perovskites, which would tune
the grain size of the perovskite films effectively. As a result,
a power conversion efficiency as high as 16.77% in
PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 based perovskite solar cells has been approached. The proposed interface-assisted method, where
the GeO2 NPs in PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 interfacial layer act on the seed-mediation role in controlling the perovskite growth,
is very simple, efficient, and different from the reported
ones.
GeO2 aqueous solutions were prepared by dissolving GeO2 powder directly into deionized water with over 8 h stirring in air at room temperature with an optimized concen-
tration of 0.3 wt. %. The GeO2 aqueous solution was spincoated on the ITO substrate at 3000 rpm/40 s and then dried
at 140 C for 2 min. This procedure was repeated several times according to experiment requirements. For PEDOT:
PSS-GeO2 composite precursor, the concentration of GeO2 aqueous solution was kept as 0.3 wt. %. Then, the prepared
GeO2 aqueous solutions were blended into the PEDOT:PSS solution with different volume ratios. The precursor of
CH3NH3I was synthesized and purified as previously reported.4,7 The mixture solution of 3:1 ratio of
CH3NH3I:PbCl2 in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent (30 wt. %) was spin coated onto the GeO2-modified ITO at 4000 rpm/40 s. After annealing (100 C, 2 h in glove box), 20 mg/ml phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester (PCBM,
Nichem Fine Technology Co., Taiwan) in chlorobenzene so-
lution was coated onto the perovskite layer at 2000 rpm/40 s.
After that, Bphen was spin-coated on PCBM at 4000 rpm/
40 s. Finally, the device was transferred to vacuum chamber under vacuum at 2 10 6 Torr for Ag electrode evaporation. The device has a structure of ITO/GeO2 (or PEDOT:PSSGeO2)/CH3NH3PbIxCl3 x/PCBM/Bphen/Ag as shown in Fig. 1. The surface morphologies of ITO, GeO2-modified ITO, were evaluated by atomic force microscopy (AFM) and
scanning electron microscopy (SEM).
First, GeO2 aqueous solution was used to modify the surface of ITO. Varied times of the surface treatment were
used to ensure the desired surface and the interface contact
between ITO and CH3NH3PbIxCl3 x. Optimized condition was determined to be three times based on the morphology evaluation and the cell performance.34 The formation of
GeO2 film onto the ITO substrate was confirmed by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Interestingly,
the crystalline property and the film morphology of the
CH3NH3PbIxCl3 x films were strongly influenced by the underlayers. The surface morphologies of treated ITO and
the crystalline properties of CH3NH3PbIxCl3 x films grown on bare ITO, GeO2-modified ITO, and PEDOT:PSS-modified ITO demonstrated that the underlayer conditions, such
as the film-forming ability, the roughness, and the coverage,
play a very important role in controlling the growth of the
perovskite active layer. As shown in Fig. 2, the device with
three-times treatment by GeO2 demonstrates the best performance, with a PCE of 12.12%, open circuit voltage (Voc) of 0.94 V, short circuit current density (Jsc) of 19.62 mA/ cm2, and fill factor (FF) of 0.66. The cell performance is
comparable with the PEDOT:PSS-based one.
More interestingly, we found that GeO2-doped PEDOT:PSS composite film could act as a very efficient
underlayer for perovskite growth. Figs. 3(a)–3(d) show the
AFM images of bare ITO/PEDOT:PSS and ITO/PEDOT:
PSS-GeO2 composite films with different GeO2 doping ratios. Clearly, island-liked GeO2 NPs were formed onto the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films. The distribution and the size of the GeO2 NPs were strongly affected by the doping ratio of GeO2 into PEDOT:PSS. Low doping ratio leads to dense distribution of GeO2 NPs with small size. In contrast, high doping ratio causes uneven distribution of GeO2 NPs with large size. The SEM images of perovskite films depos-
ited onto these underlayers are shown in Figs. 3(e)–3(h).
CH3NH3PbI3 xClx film on the PEDOT:PSS film presents
high film coverage. However, the film is composed of inter-
connected nanoscale domains with small size around 1 lm. In the cases of PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films, CH3NH3PbI3 xClx films demonstrate obviously enlarged grain domains which are associated with the distribution and
the size of GeO2 NPs onto the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films. The film coverage in the active surface area of the per-
ovskite films based on different GeO2 NPs distributions were characterized by calculating the image pixels using photoshop CS5 software.35 The size of GeO2 NPs affects the grain size and the film coverage of the perovskite films obviously, resulting in different device performance.34 It means that the
crystallization quality of the CH3NH3PbI3 xClx could be tuned by the underlayer of PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite film. It should be indicated that large voids and grain gaps
would be produced accompanying with the appearance of
large grain size of CH3NH3PbI3 xClx films.
Fig. 4(a) shows the J-V characteristics of the perovskite solar cells with PEDOT:PSS and varied PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite underlayers. The key parameters, including PCE,
Voc, Jsc, and FF, are summarized in Table I. The reference device fabricated on the PEDOT:PSS presents a PCE of 13.08%, Voc of 0.93 V, Jsc of 19.26 mA/cm 2, and FF of 0.73. In the cases of PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 underlayers, the device performance improves obviously. Particularly, in an opti-
mized case of PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 (3:1), the device demonstrates a best performance with a PCE of 16.77%, Voc of 1.01 V, Jsc of 21.35 mA/cm 2, and FF of 0.78 as shown in Fig. 4(b). Inset of Fig. 4(b) presents the histograms of the PCE
parameter in 32 cells. The PCE of the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 (3:1) underlayer based devices varies in the range of
14.81%–16.77%, indicating a better device repeatability.
Combined with the evaluations of the underlayer, the
perovskite quality and the device performance, the under-
layer condition plays an important role in the growth of the
perovskite films, which finally determines the cell perform-
ance. As a fact, the control of the final film and crystal mor-
phology of the perovskites is a critical parameter in
achieving high-performance perovskite solar cells. Film
crystallization is a complicated process in many fields. In
general, crystallization occurs via a stepwise route, from a
relatively slow nucleation step, followed by a faster growth
process. Seed-mediated growth method by various nano-
particles has been widely used in controlling the crystalline film growth.36,37 In the present case, we can see that (as
shown in Fig. 3) CH3NH3PbI3 xClx quality stronlgy depends on the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 underlayer conditions. The grain size of the CH3NH3PbI3 xClx crystal films is consistent with the size and the distribution of the GeO2 NPs onto the surface of the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films. Therefore, we assume that GeO2 NPs could be acted as the growing sites of CH3NH3PbI3 xClx films during the crystallization process. A schematic diagram of seed-mediated growth dy-
namics by GeO2 NPs for perovskite crystallization can be proposed as shown in Fig. 5. PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite precursor was first spin-coated onto the ITO substrates.
GeO2 NPs with different size could be generated by tuning the GeO2 doping ratio and the annealing condition. GeO2 NPs acted as the growing sites of crystal nucleus and perov-
skites onto the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 underlayer start to grow from the GeO2 NPs. Finally, a superior quality of perovskite films could be achieved by tuning the size of the GeO2 NPs onto the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films.
To clarify the controlling ability of GeO2 NPs on the perovskite quality, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of
PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 underlayer-dependent CH3NH3PbI3 xClx films were carried out. As shown in Fig. 6, CH3NH3 PbI3 xClx film based on PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 (3:1) underlayer demonstrates superior crystal quality compared with that
based on pristine PEDOT:PSS underlayer. Full width at half
maximum (FWHM) of the main XRD diffraction peaks in
PEDOT:PSS and PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 based perovskites were calculated.34 The FWHM data demonstrated that the main
XRD diffraction peaks of PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 based
perovskites were sharper than that of the PEDOT:PSS based
ones. It suggests an improved crystalline quality of PEDOT:
PSS-GeO2/CH3NH3PbI3 xClx with larger grain size. Noticeably, besides the peaks of (110) and (220), CH3NH3 PbI3 xClx deposited on PEDOT:PSS has many other diffraction peaks, i.e., (312), (224), and (314). However,
CH3NH3PbI3 xClx deposited on PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 (4:1) underlayer has the main peaks of only (110), (220), and
(312). Obviously, the diffraction peaks of (310), (312),
(224), and (314) in the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 based perovskites die down gradually. These features of XRD patterns suggest
the good crystalline quality of CH3NH3PbIxCl3 x film deposited on PEDOT: PSS-GeO2 (4:1).
In summary, we have investigated the underlayer effect
on the perovskite solar cells developed seed-mediated supe-
rior organometal halide films by GeO2 NPs for high performance perovskite solar cells. With optimizing treatment by
GeO2 aqueous solution, the resulting perovskite solar cell exhibits a power conversion efficiency of 12.12%, which is
comparable with the PEDOT:PSS based one. More impor-
tantly, PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films can act as an efficient underlayer for the growth of crystal perovskite films.
GeO2 NPs on the PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 composite films are regarded as the growing sites of crystal nucleus of the perov-
skite films. Superior quality of perovskite films would be
achieved by tuning the size of the GeO2 NPs. Accordingly, a best device performance with a PCE of 16.77% is obtained
in PEDOT:PSS-GeO2 (3:1) underlayer based perovskite solar cells. The finding provides a simple, efficient and
environment-friendly method for achieving highly efficient
and stable perovskite solar cells. The seed-mediated growing
route on perovskite crystallization gives a hint to seeking
other suitable nano-particle materials for fabricating highly
efficient and stable perovskite solar cells in the future.
We acknowledge financial support from the Natural
Science Foundation of China (Nos. 61307036 and
61307037) and the Natural Science Foundation of Jiangsu
Province (No. BK2010003). This project is also funded by
the Collaborative Innovation Center of Suzhou Nano
Science and Technology and by the Priority Academic
Program Development of Jiangsu Higher Education
Institutions (PAPD).
